sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: You're watching Euronews Now. Thanks for joining us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: These are the headlines this hour.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The World Health Organization warns Europe could reach more than 2 million COVID-19 deaths by March, unless countries take urgent action against the virus now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Bulgarian investigators work to find out how a bus burst into flames, with the blaze killing over 40 people on a motorway near the capital, Sofia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And NASA's DART spacecraft soars into space on a mission to knock an asteroid off course and test technology that could one day stop one from destroying planet Earth. COVID-19 patients being transferred from the Netherlands to Germany. It's a symbol of an

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: epidemic that is once again out of control on the continent. Vaccination coverage is insufficient.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Only 67% of the entire population of the European Union has received two doses of vaccine, with huge discrepancies, 86 86 in Portugal and barely 25 in Bulgaria the World Health Organization is warning that the European region could hit over 2 million covid19 deaths by March 2022. today it says the covid situation across Europe and Central Asia is very serious there is a challenging winter ahead, but we can take decisive action to stabilise the pandemic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: With almost 50,000 new cases of COVID-19 every day, Germany is one of the countries currently hardest hit by the outbreak. In several European countries, restrictions are being tightened, such as in Austria, which has re-locked down its population and made vaccinations compulsory as of February.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: On the plus side, there are new anti-Covid treatments which could soon be available to complement the vaccines, in particular a nasal spray or a pill from the American laboratory Merck which is still awaiting the green light from health regulators.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Relatives wait for news outside a hospital in the Bulgarian capital Sofia. A catastrophic

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: bus crash and subsequent inferno has left little room for hope. On board were mostly tourists being brought back home to North Macedonia from a trip to Istanbul. 46 people were killed and only 7 appear to have survived.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: I only know that my uncle, a 49-year-old from the village of Dolno Kolicani, is well, in stable condition. He only has some scratches on the face but this is nothing, he's not in danger.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: For the others, my aunt and cousin, we don't have any definitive information.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The doctors say that if they are not here, the chances are that they died at the site of the accident. The cause of the disaster is not immediately clear.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Bulgarian officials say the bus swerved off the motorway and tore a 50-metre section of the crash barrier.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But it is not yet known if the bus caught fire before or after the crash.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: No other vehicles were involved in the accident.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We are together with our North Macedonian brothers and grieve together in this tragedy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We hope the survivors recover swiftly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The victims have not yet been officially named, but officials said they include 12 children and many young people aged between 20 and 30.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: One man said he'd lost his whole family in the crash.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: he'd lost his whole family in the crash. Sweden has its first female prime minister. The new leader of the Social Democrats party,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Magdalena Andersson, received a vote of confidence on Wednesday. It follows the resignation of Stefan Löfven two weeks ago. Our reporter Per Bergfohr Nyberg has the details.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Magdalena Andersson received a standing ovation here in Parliament today when she was approved as the country's first female prime minister, 100 years after women were first allowed to vote here in Sweden. And this was a moment of huge historic significance, and especially for young girls growing up here in Sweden today, knowing that the glass ceiling has been broken and that anything is possible for both boys and girls.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Sweden is the last among the Nordic countries to actually have a female prime minister, since Denmark, Norway, Iceland, Finland, they've all had a woman at the top of government.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But it wasn't until this very morning that Andersson knew that she would have the backing of parliament. Late last night, she secured a deal with the left party about raising pensions, and that way she secured the support of that party.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And then this morning, the center party said it would also not vote against her, which meant that Andersson won the vote with just one votes margin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: However later today though she's expected to lose a vote concerning the government's budget which will mean that on the same day that she's elected the new Prime Minister she will also be forced to rule using the Conservative Opposition's budget. Now on Friday Magdalena Andersen will assume her new role as Prime minister during a ceremony at the royal palace with the Swedish king. Per Berg for Snöberg, Euronews, Stockholm, Sweden.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The human cost of the migrant crisis along the Poland and Belarus border.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: A 37-year-old man is buried. His body was found in the local forest. It's thought he probably died of hunger and from the cold.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: As part of its united response to the problems on its external eastern border, the European Union is to blacklist transport operators involved in human trafficking people into the EU. We are ready to take more sanctions against all who participate in this traffic of people, airlines, airports, travel offices, whatever.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But now the problem is not, the most important problem is not the inflow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The problem is to take care of these people, we have to provide humanitarian assistance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, the members of the Visegrad group have expressed solidarity with Poland, accusing Belarus of funneling migrants towards its border. But Hungary said the EU's policies are flawed. It supports NGOs, promotes integration programs and so on and so forth.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: NGOs, promotes integration programs and so on and so forth.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It doesn't give you money for one thing alone, and that is the physical protection of the border.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So the Hungarian position is still that the European Union must pay the cost of European border protection.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: According to the Polish authorities, the situation on the ground remains tense. Large groups of migrants are making attempts to cross into Poland and continue to throw stones, injuring border guards. NASA has launched its DART mission spacecraft to deliberately nudge an asteroid out of the

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: way as an unprecedented test.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket left the Vandenberg Space Force Base in California.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It's part of the U.S. agency's planetary defense strategy, testing the technology, which would be needed to avoid a possible collision with Earth.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The spacecraft will break free from the DART rocket and hurtle towards the asteroid more than 10 million kilometres away from Earth.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The hope is the nudge will change the asteroid's motion and the test will see by how much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Photos will be beamed back just before the impact the spacecraft should hit the rock sometime next autumn in 2022. it's five years since the Colombian government signed peace with the FARC guerrilla group after 50 years of violence stay with Euronews for our special report from Bogota on where the country stands now. We've been hearing that European leaders are calling for concerted efforts to step up humanitarian aid for the hundreds of migrants still trapped in extreme conditions between Belarus and Poland.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Today, NGO Human Rights Watch has released a report calling for just that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And joining me from London is Ben Ward, Human Rights Watch deputy director for Europe and Central Asia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Ben Ward, the EU says it wants to do more on humanitarian efforts, but what exactly is it proposing and is it enough?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: It's a very important effort, initiative, but it's only focused on what's happening on the Belarus side of the border.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And while Belarus is very much responsible for orchestrating this crisis, our research has shown that Poland's actions are exacerbating the suffering that people are experiencing, both because of its pushbacks of migrants and asylum seekers across the border, in some cases repeatedly, and also because it's denying humanitarian access in the border area where it's declared a state of emergency. And we feel that the European Union really ought to be focusing much more on that as well as the situation on the Belarus side.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So what exactly then do you see as the EU's role in all of this?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, the European Union obviously has a duty to protect its borders and obviously has a duty to make sure at the same time that it respects the rights of people who are at those borders. And I think so far its focus has been only on the former and not sufficiently on the latter. It hasn't brought enough pressure to bear on Poland to make sure that it is complying with European Union law around access to asylum.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And I think even more importantly or more urgently perhaps, it hasn't put enough pressure on Poland to open up that secure area around the border to humanitarian organizations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And what we're seeing is lots of people trapped actually on the Polish side of the border who are in forests, living in the open, in some cases for days or even weeks, without access to food and water. And we are seeing deaths. And I think that that is something that really ought not to be happening in European Union territory.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But as you say, those people are there. They're trapped in extreme conditions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Is it realistic, do you think, to expect Belarus or Poland to change their stance towards them? Well, Belarus is obviously an extremely abusive government. It's not just abusive in the context of this particular situation. It's abusive more generally. And obviously, that's the context in which this particular crisis has come about. One of the reasons the situation is so difficult in Belarus is because most civil society organizations are no longer present. They've been liquidated and their activists are no longer able to work. But the European Union does have much more ability to influence the situation on the Polish side of the border. And I think it's also right to expect a higher standard of conduct from the European Union member state that is a democracy and that has pledged to respect basic principles of human rights. And so, with a proper humanitarian access and with more emphasis on making sure that people who declare an intention to seek asylum are given access to a proper process.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We could see a significant shift, I think, in the situation on the Polish side of the border.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: With more details on the DART mission, I'm joined from California by Ian Carnelli, who is project manager with the HERA project at the European Space Agency.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Ian Carnely, thanks so much for joining us just shortly after the launch of the DART mission.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: It's the Double Asteroid Redirection Test Mission. It sounds a little bit like the stuff of many a Hollywood sci-fi blockbuster, but how real is the threat to planet Earth from these asteroids?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But how real is the threat to planet Earth from these asteroids?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Good morning, Sarence. Thank you for inviting me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Today there is no incoming asteroid on a collision course with Earth, so rest assured. But this is actually the perfect moment to test our technology and make sure we have an insurance policy to protect our planet.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Because asteroid impacts have happened in the past, but it's the only natural hazard that we can not only predict, but we can also prevent. And the DART mission is the first step humanity is taking to protect planet Earth from future impacts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Well, ESA will be supporting DART via its own HERA mission from 2024. What will ESA's role be exactly?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Correct. Although DART and HERA were conceived to be independent missions, they're actually complementary.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So HERA will be launched in October 2024.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It's currently being integrated in Bremen by OHP, and its purpose is to gather all the scientific data, THE DATA IS DATA. IT IS A PROPERTY CREATED BY OHP AND ITS PURPOSE IS TO GATHER ALL THE SCIENTIFIC DATA, THE PROPERTIES OF THE ASTEROID, UNDERSTAND WHAT IS MADE OF, WHAT KIND OF MINERALS AND ALL THE PHYSICAL AND DYNAMICAL PROPERTIES SO THAT BASICALLY WE CAN UNDERSTAND EXACTLY WHAT HAS HAPPENED DURING THE DART impact. And all of this data will be used by more than 300 scientists around the world to validate our models so that in the future, if we have to design a real mission to deflect an asteroid, we will have all of the data, all of the models validated to build the perfect planetary defence system.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Well, that science sounds very complex.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Does it have any other applications beyond planetary defence?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, all of the technology we're using is actually technology that is on board many other satellites.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And there are satellites that provide to citizens every day many services like positioning systems telecommunications applications on Earth from Earth observation data so both Hera and Dart are actually technology demonstration missions and this technology will be used for a number of many many many applications okay well Ian Connelly that's very interesting thanks so much for joining us thank you very much the Turkish lira has crashed almost as much as 15 to an all-time low. It follows recent interest rate cuts for the third consecutive month last

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: week. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan praised the cuts and recently declared Turkey was fighting an economic war of independence. Inflation is already running at an annual rate of 20%.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thousands of miners have protested outside a government building in the Bosnian capital Sarajevo.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The demonstration follows government plans to restructure indebted coal mines as part of a programme to switch to renewable energy sources.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But it involves job and 30% wage cuts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Employees from 7 out of 11 coal mines stopped work and took part.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: from seven out of 11 coal mines stopped work and took part.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The man jailed for the 2007 murder of British student Meredith Kircher in central Italy has been freed early. Rudy Guede has completed 13 years of a 16-year sentence. Kircher's American flatmate Amanda Knox and her Italian boyfriend were also initially convicted, but were eventually acquitted on appeal. All three have denied killing Kircher.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The suspect in the Wisconsin parade crash, Daryl Brooks, will now face six charges of first-degree intentional homicide. An eight-year-old boy has become the latest person to die as a result of being hit by an SUV at full speed at the Christmas parade.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The charges carry a mandatory life sentence if convicted.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Bail was set at US$5 million and a preliminary hearing is scheduled for January. Colombia, doctor Juan Manuel Santos Calderón. That's it for now, but stay with us as we bring you all the latest from across Europe and beyond.
